doc.field: This is a diorama of the layout of the Aztec Ruins. The kivas, or round structures, are thought to have been used for ceremonial purposes, especially the large one in the center. The <a href"http:www.flickr.comphotosbaggis2197748005inphotostream">middens<a> are located near the southwest (bottom right) corner of the pueblo. I linked many of the pictures to their location on this display. Unfortunately I didn't realize it would get so muddled toward the top. That must have been one of the more interesting areas. The pueblo is roughly oriented toward the cardinal directions with north being at the top.
newmexico model ruins rooms aztec diorama kiva aztecruins

Thirty years after its discovery, the <a href"http:www.nps.govazru">Aztec Ruins<a>, in 1889 came into private hands. This finally helped the site to achieve some protection from looting. This is <a href"http:flickr.comphotosbaggis2198535954">area #6<a> on the model.
snow newmexico wall ruins aztec room pueblo prehistoric aztecruins aztecruinsnationalmonument

When originally found in 1859, many of the rooms at the <a href"http:www.nps.govazru">Aztec Ruins<a> were undisturbed. Unfortunately, by 1878, it was noted by the archaeologist, Lewis H. Morgan, that about half of the stones at the site had been carted away by the recent influx of white settlers. This is <a href"http:flickr.comphotosbaggis2198535954">area #5<a> on the model.
snow newmexico wall ruins aztec room pueblo prehistoric aztecruins aztecruinsnationalmonument

The <a href"http:www.nps.govazru">Aztec Ruins<a> overlooks the Animas River which is a tributary of the San Juan and Colorado Rivers. Construction in this area began in the late 11th century with occupation of the site continuing through to the late 13th century when it was abandoned. This is <a href"http:flickr.comphotosbaggis2198535954">area #13<a> on the model.
wood sky snow newmexico tree wall clouds ruins rooms aztec spokes pueblo doorway prehistoric sanjuancounty aztecruins aztecruinsnationalmonument

These are the outer walls and rooms of the <a href"http:www.nps.govazru">Aztec Ruins<a>. These structures weren't actually built by the Aztecs but were rather named so by those who had heard the stories of Cortez from down south. The Aztecs were actually not in the picture until around AD 1200 and they were thought to have been mercenaries from the north. Still, this structure, and others in the area are not attributed to the Aztecs. This is <a href"http:flickr.comphotosbaggis2198535954">area #2<a> on the model.
snow newmexico wall ruins aztec room pueblo prehistoric aztecruins aztecruinsnationalmonument

This is the modern entrance to the <a href"http:www.nps.govazru">Aztec Ruins<a>. The construction of this pueblo began around AD 1000. This is <a href"http:flickr.comphotosbaggis2198535954">area #1<a> on the model looking south.
snow newmexico wall ruins aztec room pueblo prehistoric aztecruins aztecruinsnationalmonument

This collection of pottery was held at the beginning of the back room display where all of the photographed artifacts in this set were held. This case had no explanation and I took this mostly for the blowfish-looking vessel on the right. If I had to choose that these were either the <a href"http:www.flickr.comphotosbaggis2197753473inphotostream">Chaco<a> or the <a href"http:www.flickr.comphotosbaggis2197752917inphotostream">Mesa Verde<a>-style pottery as given by their brief descriptions, I'd have to go with Mesa Verde at least for the piece on the left because it has a decorated rim and has solid designs. The container in the back may be Chacoan based on its hatched design. The piece on the right I am not willing to take a guess with. It should also be noted, however, that there are a lot of different pottery styles in the area beyond just the Chaco and Mesa Verde with probable overlap between them all so classifying may be harder than it seems. I'll leave the ceramic typologies to the professionals.
newmexico design ceramics aztec style pottery tactile aztecruins

A midden pile, or trash heap, can tell a lot about the culture living at the site in question. This is a piece of Mesa Verde-style ceramic which, when found in context can help tell who and when lived in an area at a given time. Not only can the ceramic itself be dated, but the charcoal seen in this replica could also be dated to give more support to the date of the pottery and the <a href"http:www.flickr.comphotosbaggis2197748005inphotostream">overall<a> occupation time frame of the people in the area.
aztecruins newmexico aztec stratigraphy midden garbage layers levels profile wall archaeology bones ceramics pottery

This is a general map of the <a href"http:www.firstpeople.usarticlesThe-Salmon-RuinsThe-Salmon-Ruins.html">Salmon Ruins<a>. The layout is much like that of the <a href"http:flickr.comphotosbaggis2198535954">Aztec Ruins<a> with a large kiva toward the south end of the pueblo by itself and one directly north of it that is slightly smaller. These two kivas line up exactly on a north orientation, but the rest of the pueblo is slightly askew. Odd that they both are set up in the same exact manner with the majority of the rooms being on the north side of the pueblo. The dotted lines on the left are thought to be where walls once existed, but may have been scavenged for rock or fallen over time. The Salmon Ruins are named after the pioneer, Peter Milton Salmon, and his son George P. Salmon, who bought the land near the ruins in 1877, and built a homestead in 1900. The homestead is a stone's-throw away from the ruins.
newmexico abandoned fire layout living rooms map sanjuan kiva bloomfield ceremonial butchering foodprocessing salmonruins turkeypens puebloruinheritagepark sanjuancountymuseum toolmanufacturing

This is the <a href"http:www.flickr.comphotosbaggis2209780543inphotostream">Great Kiva<a> at the south end of the Salmon Ruins that was one of the original constructions done by the Chacoans. It is semi-subterranean and has a bench that goes around its periphery that has holds for supporting wood features that would keep up the roof. In the center of the kiva would be a fire pit with a ventilator shaft for fresh air, and a hole in the floor called a sipapu, which symbolized the entrance to the spirit world below. Like the Great Kiva at the <a href"http:www.flickr.comphotosbaggis2201677843">Aztec Ruins<a> this Great Kiva has a anteroom, although less obvious, on the north end that functioned as either a storage area or for ceremonies. The Tower Kiva and the majority of the Salmon Pueblo can be seen in the distance to the north.
snow newmexico sanjuan round kiva bloomfield ceremonial sipapu salmonruins greatkiva puebloruinheritagepark sanjuancountymuseum

Kim seems very unwilling to pose as a scale for the rung ladder. This was one of <a href"http:www.flickr.comphotosbaggis2197755501inphotostream">two<a> types of ladders found at the Aztec ruins. This ladder seems like it would be more stable and easier to use. For some reason when I think of Chaco Canyon and Mesa Verde, I think of defensive fortresses. These ladders seem like they would be better used in the inner walls rather than on the outer walls where the <a href"http:www.flickr.comphotosbaggis2197755501inphotostream">notched<a> ladder might be more useful.
newmexico kim aztec ladder rungs aztecruins

These soapstone slabs were found buried in the Great Kiva. The purpose for these is unknown. However, underneath these slabs was a bag of turquoise powder and an animal fetish. These slabs remind me of a smaller version of the altars I've seen in Guatemala's <a href"http:flickr.comphotosbaggis35027367inset-783904">Abaj Takalik<a>. However, the Guatemalan altars predate the <a href"http:www.nps.govazru">Aztec Ruins<a> by roughly 900 years.
newmexico window stone ruins aztec room pueblo altar doorway ladder passage prehistoric kiva slabs passageway ceremonial aztecruins roundroom aztecruinsnationalmonument

This is the Aztec theatre that sits along the main road of the city Aztec. Aztec got its name from the <a href"http:www.nps.govazru">ruins<a> that are nearby. The sign reminds me of a 1950s theatre sign.
red newmexico sign town theatre aztec pueblo

Stuck in a sharp concavity is a petroglyph that appears to be a person. Below it is another figure. At the <a href"http:www.flickr.comphotosbaggissets72157603729317658">Aztec Ruins<a> there was a video running telling of the importance of ants, which showed the Chaco people how to live. This figure might possibly represent an ant, although I generally don't try to analyze these figures without any background knowledge.
newmexico stone ruins pueblo ruin nationalparkservice chaco chacocanyon prehistoric petroglyph carvings unavida chacoculturenationalhistoricpark

This is one of the many small kivas in the east wing of Pueblo Bonito. The pillasters are constructed to hold logs that eventually come together to form the roof. An example of this can be seen in part at the <a href"http:www.flickr.comphotosbaggis2201686895">Aztec Ruins<a>. The pieces build on each other upwards until they leave only a hole at the top over the center of the kiva to allow for smoke to exit the room. This is <a href"http:flickr.comphotosbaggis2236502758inphotostream">Kiva<a> on the map.
snow newmexico ruins pueblo columns canyon round nationalparkservice chacocanyon kiva pueblobonito chacoculturenationalhistoricpark
